Why the Ocean Ecosystem needs Whales





	


		


	
		


			

						
							

					
				Research			

					
				Why the Ocean Ecosystem needs Whales
			
					
				 Ramya NareshJuly 26, 2014			

					
				All species big and small have a role to play in the natural world defining the habitat and the ecosystem they live in. Now scientists have found the important tasks whales have been given to maintain the health of the oceans. A recent study shows that these giant mammals have an influence on global carbon storage, the health of commercial fisheries and are important part of the ocean ecosystem living and even after death.





 “For a long time, whales have been considered too rare to make much of a difference in the oceans,” said University of Vermont conservation biologist Joe Roman. 

In order to understand the ecological significance of whales better, Roman and a team of biologists compared the statistics from decades of research on whales around the globe and came to the conclusion that whales matter a lot to the well-being of the oceanic ecosystem.

The decline in great whale numbers, estimated to be at least 66% and perhaps as high as 90%, has likely altered the structure and function of the oceans,” Roman and his colleagues write in the July 3, 2014, online edition of Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, “but recovery is possible and in many cases is already underway.”

The Whale’s Role

Baleen and sperm whales, known collectively as the “great whales,” include the largest animals to have ever lived on Earth.

Here are some important roles they play in the ocean,

Food Chain – Because of their high food intake, whales eat a large number of fishes and vertebrates in the ocean. They are themselves prey to other predators like killer whales, and distribute nutrients through the water. This makes them an important part of the food chain.

“As humpbacks, gray whales, sperm whales and other cetaceans recover from centuries of overhunting, we are beginning to see that they also play an important role in the ocean,” Roman said. “Among their many ecological roles, whales recycle nutrients and enhance primary productivity in areas where they feed.”

 Whale Fall – Even their carcasses, dropping to the seafloor, provide habitat for many species that only exist on these “whale falls.” In fact, the researchers fear there are many invertebrates that became extinct when whales were hunted to death decades ago and their number had suddenly plummeted leaving no ‘homes’ for the invertebrates.

Whale Pump – Whales catch their prey at ocean depths and release the faecal plumes in the surface. This supports plankton growth and the whole process is called whale pump.

High to low latitudes – Whales also move nutrients thousands of miles from productive feeding areas at high latitudes to calving areas at lower latitudes.

The researchers say that traditionally commercial fishermen sea whales as a competitor in the waters, but their study explains that the opposite is true. By their presence, whales increase the entire population of a gamut of ocean dwelling species.

 “As long-lived species, they enhance the predictability and stability of marine ecosystems,” Roman said.

Saving Whales

Despite their important function, large size and significance in mythology whales have suffered in the hands of humans. Seven out of the thirteen great whale species are classified as endangered or vulnerable, even after decades of protection.

Ocean ecosystems are threatened by increasing temperatures and acidification. Other factors such as collision with ships, entanglement in fishing nets cause damage to whales. Whales are rendered deaf by the noise from shipping activity. Oil rigs affect their feeding and breeding grounds and cause changes in their migratory path.

The study authors believe, new observations of whales will provide a more accurate understanding of historical population dynamics and “are likely to provide evidence of undervalued whale ecosystem services,”

“This area of research will improve estimates of the benefits — some of which, no doubt, remain to be discovered — of an ocean repopulated by the great whales.”

Whales roam through all of the world’s oceans and communicate with complex and mysterious sounds. The blue whale can reach lengths of more than 100 feet and weigh up to 200 tons—as much as 33 elephants.  Despite living in the water, whales breathe air. And like humans, they are warm-blooded mammals who nurse their young. A thick layer of fat called blubber insulates them from cold ocean waters.

Some whales are known as baleen whales including blue whale, right whale, bowhead whale, sei whale and gray whale. They get the name because of the special bristle-like structures in their mouths (called baleen) that strains food from the water. Other whales, such as beluga or sperm whales, have teeth.

				Ramya is a homemaker who likes to live in harmony with Nature, believing that each form of life is a wonder in itself.   She values living in the present and looks forward to each day in all its freshness.
She is a Senior Writer with India's Endangered.

			3 thoughts on “Why the Ocean Ecosystem needs Whales”		



		
		
					
			
				
					
												Dr Jaishree Sikka says:					


					
						July 29, 2014 at 11:43 am					


									

				
					Dear Ramya,

Your article is very interesting. Being a teacher of ecology i can understand the importance of each n every species in ecosystem. Unfortunately as a part of biosphere we have failed to recognize our role and destroying the natural balance existing in it.

J.Sikka

				


				Reply
			
		
		
			
				
					
												Atula Gupta says:					


					
						July 29, 2014 at 1:07 pm					


									

				
					Thank you for your comment. Indeed, as human population grows, nature’s balance is destroyed harming many of the species that thrive on land and in oceans. Hope, people recognise their importance in due time. Regards, Atula

				


				Reply

<article id="post-3201" class="post-3201 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-research-news tag-ecosystem tag-oceans tag-threat-to-whales tag-whales">
						<div class="entry-thumbnail">
				<img width="500" height="362" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://indiasendangered.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/4786980989_569bb557db_z-e1406367353442.jpg" class="attachment-cenote-full-width size-cenote-full-width wp-post-image" alt="" decoding="async">			</div>

					<div class="tg-top-cat">
				<span class="cat-links"><a href="https://indiasendangered.com/category/news/research-news/" rel="category tag" target="_blank">Research</a></span>			</div>

					<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title">Why the Ocean Ecosystem needs Whales</h1>
			</header>
					<div class="entry-meta">
				<span class="byline"> <span class="author vcard"><a class="url fn n" href="https://indiasendangered.com/author/ramya-naresh/" target="_blank">Ramya Naresh</a></span></span><span class="posted-on"><a href="https://indiasendangered.com/why-the-ocean-ecosystem-needs-whales/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank"><time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2014-07-26T15:13:53+05:30">July 26, 2014</time></a></span>			</div>

					<div class="entry-content">
				<p class="first-child "><strong><span title="A" class="cenote-drop-cap">A</span>ll species big and small have a role to play in the natural world defining the habitat and the ecosystem they live in. Now scientists have found the important tasks whales have been given to maintain the health of the oceans. A recent study shows that <a href="http://indiasendangered.com/restoration-of-coral-reefs-best-way-to-save-millions-of-human-lives/" target="_blank">these giant mammals have an influence on global carbon storage</a>, the health of commercial fisheries and are important part of the ocean ecosystem living and even after death.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong><a href="http://indiasendangered.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/4786980989_569bb557db_z.jpg" target="_blank"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-3202" title="4786980989_569bb557db_z" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://indiasendangered.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/4786980989_569bb557db_z-e1406367353442.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="362"></a><br>

</strong></p>

<blockquote><p><strong> “For a long time, whales have been considered too rare to make much of a difference in the oceans,” said University of Vermont conservation biologist Joe Roman. </strong></p>
</blockquote>
<p><strong>In order to understand the ecological significance of whales better, Roman and a team of biologists compared the statistics from decades of research on whales around the globe and came to the conclusion that whales matter a lot to the well-being of the oceanic ecosystem.</strong></p>

<p><strong>The decline in great whale numbers, estimated to be at least 66% and perhaps as high as 90%, has likely altered the structure and function of the oceans,” Roman and his colleagues write in the July 3, 2014, online edition of Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, “but recovery is possible and in many cases is already underway.”</strong></p>

<h2><span style="color: #008000;">The Whale’s Role</span></h2>

<p><strong>Baleen and sperm whales, known collectively as the “great whales,” include the largest animals to have ever lived on Earth.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Here are some important roles they play in the ocean,</strong></p>

<p><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Food Chain</span> – Because of their high food intake, whales eat a large number of fishes and vertebrates in the ocean. They are themselves prey to other predators like killer whales, and distribute nutrients through the water. This makes them an important part of the food chain.</strong></p>

<blockquote><p><strong>“As humpbacks, gray whales, sperm whales and other cetaceans recover from centuries of overhunting, we are beginning to see that they also play an important role in the ocean,” Roman said. “Among their many ecological roles, whales recycle nutrients and enhance primary productivity in areas where they feed.”</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<p><strong><span style="color: #008000;"> Whale Fall</span> – Even their carcasses, dropping to the seafloor, provide habitat for many species that only exist on these “whale falls.” In fact, the researchers fear there are many invertebrates that became extinct when whales were hunted to death decades ago and their number had suddenly plummeted leaving no ‘homes’ for the invertebrates.</strong></p>

<p><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Whale Pump</span> – Whales catch their prey at ocean depths and release the faecal plumes in the surface. This supports plankton growth and the whole process is called whale pump.</strong></p>

<p><strong><span style="color: #008000;">High to low latitudes</span> – Whales also move nutrients thousands of miles from productive feeding areas at high latitudes to calving areas at lower latitudes.</strong></p>

<p><strong>The researchers say that traditionally commercial fishermen sea whales as a competitor in the waters, but their study explains that the opposite is true. By their presence, whales increase the entire population of a gamut of ocean dwelling species.</strong></p>

<blockquote><p><strong> “As long-lived species, they enhance the predictability and stability of marine ecosystems,” Roman said.</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<h2><span style="color: #008000;">Saving Whales</span></h2>

<p><strong>Despite their important function, large size and significance in mythology whales have suffered in the hands of humans. Seven out of the thirteen great whale species are classified as endangered or vulnerable, even after decades of protection.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Ocean ecosystems are threatened by increasing temperatures and acidification. Other factors such as collision with ships, entanglement in fishing nets cause damage to whales. Whales are rendered deaf by the noise from shipping activity. Oil rigs affect their feeding and breeding grounds and cause changes in their migratory path.</strong></p>

<p><strong>The study authors believe, new observations of whales will provide a more accurate understanding of historical population dynamics and “are likely to provide evidence of undervalued whale ecosystem services,”</strong></p>

<blockquote><p><strong>“This area of research will improve estimates of the benefits — some of which, no doubt, remain to be discovered — of an ocean repopulated by the great whales.”</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<p><strong>Whales roam through all of the world’s oceans and communicate with complex and mysterious sounds. The blue whale can reach lengths of more than 100 feet and weigh up to 200 tons—as much as 33 elephants.  Despite living in the water, whales breathe air. And like humans, they are warm-blooded mammals who nurse their young. A thick layer of fat called blubber insulates them from cold ocean waters.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Some whales are known as baleen whales including blue whale, right whale, bowhead whale, sei whale and gray whale. They get the name because of the special bristle-like structures in their mouths (called baleen) that strains food from the water. Other whales, such as beluga or sperm whales, have teeth.</strong></p>
